postcard
stamp 14
postmark CHICAGO IL 606  7 JUNE 1986 - PM
image of building
5555 North Sheridan Road, Apt. 610
Chicago, Illinois 60640
Jack Conroy
701 Fisk Ave.
Moberly, Missouri 65270

Dear Jack -

I was delighted to hear from you - Often I wondered about you.

Sorry about your loss of Gladys. Dave Rothstein died in 1983 - I did
not know of Paul Romains death.

In any case you & I are still kicking dust - altho   I just came back from a

heart attack hospital stay. I expect to be back in my office in a couple of months.

Actually most of the time I spent at the office was entertaining old left wing

buddies who drop around to see if I'm still about. It would be the greatest pleasure
to see you again & to take you to Berghoff for a weiner-schnitzel & beer. Could that
be?    ? Meyer     your face should be on the stamp

postcard
stamp 1c
postmark WILTON CONN OCT 11 1933
Jack Conroy
R.F.D #4
Moberly, Missouri

Nod Hill,
Wilton, Conn.,
Oct. 10, 1933
Dear Conroy,
I'll be glad to review "The Disinherited" for the underlined:  Nation if they'll let me have it. I've done two or 3 reviews for the New Republic, but none for the underlined: Nation. Can you pull any strings? I'll send your suggestion about the circulars on to Harcourts, & I'll be grateful to you.  Of course the book'll never make back the $200 advance I got, so I have to find all the solace I can in such things. Snow sent me two issues of the underlined: Anvil - he's a damn fine egg & I read the first with keen interest, but the 2nd I have not got to, since we've been moving. Your criticism is well-founded, but unfortunately the negative side is all that my experience includes, and so I must leave the affirmative for the lads who can deal with it honestly, and certainly with more effectiveness than I could ever muster. But the negative, I believe, has its uses.
Yours. George Milburn

postcard
stamp 1 c
postmark MEDFORD OKLA APR 20  12 3- PM
Jack Conroy
Moberly Missouri

Medford, Okla..
April 18, 1935
Dear Conroy,

Please accept my belated congratulations to a Guggenheim fellowship. I feel

flattered to have been able to get in my 2₵ worth. I wrote Moe a personal letter
from London & had a long talk with him when I came through New York.
Go to it and Good luck to you!

Yours,    George Milburn

apdo, 633 Cuernavaca unclear Mexico
4 Jan 67
Dear Jack, ole sock,
I was happy to hear from you, and believe me I do understand and sympathize with the difficulties (as well as the glories) of your transplanation to Missouri soil. I can see by the picture you drew for me that you're a bit tied up, but not er soiled. But what's that muff in the mouth, you fag in disguise. 
What is California Tar Pit Society? Ole ripwinker miller don kno fur nothin.
I liked Swados' anthology. It's a better idea than Moore-Madden So Ill U Press' idea. Yet, by the prospectus, the book looks good. So glad to be with Conroy, Ames, Howe, Green, Chametzsky, Hoffman and the other ole greats! But boy did I find the Traven bit a tough one to crack: talking to an audience that knows nothing about the books of a complex, profound and unique writer. I hope it reads as serious as my sweat. 
Jack, you need only write a brief note, saying that you consent to my discussing bids for your literary property. This note is only a gents' agreement that I am getting a chance to get bids for you; it's not conclusive or fatal. Since I already HAVE bids on your bin of treasures, I need only your word. Will you send it, however informally? I'll try to get at least 40 grand for you. And you don't have to part with Everything:---just a representative chunk of your archives. 
Ames & I are writing. He sounds swell. I hope to get down there this month, with a señorita friend of mine, to test his hammocks & hospitality. Will give you a full & juicy report.
Jack, I'm having a bit of luck, too. Will send some new publications on BT soon. If you send me the letter, we may get to pay dirt in March '67.
Feliz año neuvo, unclear!
Su amigo
Charlie The (ex) chicken chaser.
PS I just got back from my Pacific beach where I live in a mud walled hut with mud floor. Killed 3 scorpions only one of whom stung me! Also killed a few bottles & underlined: scored  a few senoritas! ooaah

apdo, 633 Cuernavaca unclear Mexico
10 Mar 67
Dear Jack,
thanks, for yours of Feb 28 which crossed with mine in th blue above the Rio Grande. We'll have to stop crossing letters and get together. 
Your letter says nothing about the Conroy Archives, you ole fox, and I'd come to see you even if you were nude or archives; but let me tell ya th libraries are really thirsting for your archives, and if I have anything to d-do with th deal, they'll pay well for the privelege of peering into the (paper) parts of the one & only (no longer in captivity) Conroy.
I am indeed sorry to hear about those shits in the UnEmployment Bureaucracy, but don't give up: I got a claim almost a year after its first rebuff, by continual reapplication, over the objections of employer, union, government officials and everybody except one man in the State central office who admired my case: Hope you can do somewhat th same.
THE BRIDGE is exciting to us, down here. We wonder how it will splash down. It could hardly do better than N V which sold more than 8,000 and is still selling. I'm trying a 'study' of the BRIDGE, but would rather be writing poems.
Yes, will try your friend Wagoner, whose work I've liked, what I've seen of it. One other lil thing: I never saw your full review of N V in Chicago Trib, but will hope to see it this trip. Th dame in PUBLISHERS' WKLY may well find herself left behind; the book is 100 times greater than she seems to think poor gal.
I've met, with pleasure, yr friends Keaney & Ames, but am busier than a cat on a hot printer's slab trying to cover commas (I just invented this, ©, see), & hope to see more of them later. Maybe you'll venture down again; I'll try to fix up a lecture or expense jaunt for you, the very which I can't fix up for me: 
Hoping to see you before the Ides of March march into April. 
I'm your Charlie
PS I do hope your Gladys is one, or two, up on the knee. How does she like your cooking!?
PS2 For Gladys, from my garden: pressed leaf

% The Newberry / 60 W.Walton, Chicago 60610
26 April 67
Dear Jack:
excuse th paper, but I hope to earn better in time.
As planned, I had a luncheon confab with Ralph McCoy, director of Libraries at So. Ill. Univ, and we discussed only Conroy & Conroy, & letters to Conroy. They're with you all th way (if they can get you!). We were very serious, and partook of soup & stuffings with my stuff thrown in, all at Rickett's, a blithely temperate spot without a spigot on th premises.
I told them, as you advised me, there's no chance of getting your archives. But I suggested that they bid on the Mencken letters, as a beginning; and if they please you, perhaps you will feel disposed to go on to bigger committments. I hope you like this idea. They have to like it, for it's the only feasible one for now.
To resume my idea, as you heard it on Tuesday, I will say that if we get the Mencken letters together, and you supply a brief personal memo of the circumstances of your connection with HLM, and supply some of your letters to him, it can be published in a plump quarterly, with the greatest of ease and 'gusto' (a Mexicanism much employed by HLM, and CHM...). From the quarterly, it will certainly be picked up by one of the 'proletarian.' Conroy-hungry presses, perhaps by So. Ill, Un. Press (if they get their money-press repaired in th mean time, th penny-mad idealists). 
To repeat what I said to you, I think the Mencken letters with JC memo is a good place to begin, both emotionally and chronologically. Anything that you write on HLM now can be incorporated into your memoirs. It will be a logical and easy beginning. 
If you still feel that way, I will con todo gusto come to Moberly after May 11 and help you in any way I can to sort and label the various categories of your very exciting and unique archives. While I am there, we can discuss (between rounds of beer) the near future. I can see the far f.
I think I told you, gently and between the lines, that Texass is leary of us'ns, th prol, th radical, the true. Even leary of my great friend BT. However else we may regard So Ill Un, it is friendly to our field, it has H. Moore (he may be there in May, certainly in June), and it has already started its prol & radical collections. The prices are getting levelled out; the 'going' price is the thing, now. And I'm glad that with you, and with almost everybody else, price is the lesser consideration. As I see it, your archives are priceless. Anything under that is just regular stuff. 
So here you have, again, too many words. I enjoy talking to you, and I hope that your Readin Machine ain't choked up. As for your Ritin Machine, mud in yore eyen!
Yr slave, (with [?]] shop chains arizen & cast off!)
Charlie

newspaper clipping
Des Moines Register  sat., Sept. 30, 1967  PAGE 10
PRICES MIXED ON IOWA HOGS    see over -

Colorado State College (Pueblo, Colo.) wants you to speak, and they pay only about 100,

plus all the whisky you can drink - so I know you'll go! They'll contact you.

to seek for work, to find it and fight to hold it; Man, we're in a different world! Will the Employment Commissioned and Cunt-to-Casket Ensured ever believe what that world was like? That's what we have to show them, what you already have.
Each night (before getting in on top of each other) my fair Lynn and I get down on our consupiscient knees and prey to Godz Unknown and Godots suspected that you will put pen to page in simple and horny slang to tell what the Moberly Prowler and Howler lived through to get to your present girth, height, and clarity of bitterness. You were spared. Others perished. You were there. You did it. You have told, or half told, much of a great story. For YOUR sake as well as your heirs, get that fuckin autobiography a-goin, even if you clobber your young uns, your bed-mate and beer buddies. Don't leave us hanging on the back gates of gossip, picking the ole bones of posterity to find the Truth: tell us, Truestaff Jack! and RIP among the bottles and bladders of memory. Any of us may cop out for the boneyard any day, and I'll resent if I happen to outlast you by a few infirmities and have to keep on wondering and waiting to fill in the Big Gaps in your terrible, splendid and incomplete Life.
If you love us, give us you.
Love!
Charlie
(Lynn writes under me)
Tell Clint his Tobacco 3 00 is planted, not gone to seed & cigars will bloom , {nice of our trips)! C

upside down  SERVICIO AEREO
CORREOS - MEXICO
TARJETA CARTA
SERVIVIO AEREO

ESTADO Mex.

in pencil 1963
21 July
Dear Jack:

We got a nice note from the Medfords of Chicago, after they'd left Mexico.

Send our apologies, if you write to the.

We only get our mail around once a week, when we go to town.
I saw that N.Y. Review of Bks did us Proles? up.  True?
 We're very busy & productive. Praise the lord & pass the ammunition -

(for Zapata y liberitad)         Charlie

1968
Labor Day
Apdo 633
Cuernavaca, Mor -1, Mexico
Dear Jack Conroy:

Your DISINHERITED meant a great deal to me, not only on its own strength, its own life force, but

because I came from that world, too. Although I was brought up on a farm, I went seeking work in the
Thirties: ranch, factory, restaurant, a few mines, and finally construction. Your people, your family,
your wanderings and conclusions are real to this reader. I look forward to reading whatever else you care
to write. Stories? Memories? Autobiographies? whatever, you've got one eager reader waiting to go to work
on your pages!

I hope to be in Chicago in Sept, possibly October, and I'd like to visit you some afternoon when you're not

teaching and writing. (I guess you teach? I don't, I'm still a proletarian, with a pen, these days). I lived and
struggled in Chicago, wrote about it, but haven't sold it yet. We could talk about the old days. By the way, I
gave your DISINHERITED to Mr. Traven, who read it and liked it. His world!

If you care to write me % Box 16141, Houston 22, Texas, giving me yr address, I could let you know when I'm

coming to Chicago area.

Best wished for you & your family of words.
 Sincerely,

[signed] Charlie Miller

Charles H. Miller

There I got my stove pipes and there Lynn & I will go to explore the smokey taverns, hoisting a few in far-off tribute to you!
We are working on a book related to Zapata and the Revolution, we don't miss Mexico very much, after having it up to our cerebellums for 2 yrs; and we don't miss the reactionary government very much (there's enough of it here!), but we will go back in a few months to do more work. Our films will be out this season, and we'll let you know if one gets within a six-pack of Moberly. 
We do miss our horses, but there are plenty of them here, and if we please we may have them next spring, for the stable waits right there under the mulberry tree.
Do write us a Peeps report on the Taverns of Moberly, the writings of Conroy and all else that we'd like to hear. We hear that you've been lecturing around, so I hope the plains wolves are shying away from your door. Meantime our stable door is Always Open if you get near here.
Love
Charlie & Lynn
I've been out in the wood sawing. Lynn has hot biscuits for breakfast.

in pencil 1968
Box 61 - Mt Vernon, [P?]a 52314
6 Dec
Dear Jack ole sock,

its just possible that my bride & I may be  whizzing throu [sic] or close to Moberly on Wed. Dec 13, and

if so we'll give you a call, and if possible we'll behold you in your lair, even as to resting our accelerator
footsies some hours if not our tongues & ears.

Drop me a line? - espec. if ur [your] hse [house] has Black Plague, Leprosy, Chinese measles, Mexican Malaria, Moberly

Mumps or merely all Mexican clap, syph & cancer!

Love, with roses, pussy & whiskey.  yrs. for the road
    Charlie & Lynn

on side much news, gossip & slander when we meet

in pencil 1968
Box 66 - Mt Vernon, Pa.?
16 Dec
Dear Jack & Gladys,

We hope to see you before too long, p'haps 19-20, enroute south.
But I forgot!  Had a great time at Carlton?, & many woods re the Conroy. Miscellany can use

material. Why don't you give them a piece of your memoir? They pay a bit, like 100-150 for a good
piece (you're still a good piece, you missouri ass, you!) and the prestige is precious.  I'm giving Miscellany
a bit too.

It will be so good to see you, if we can get free of the mix-up here.
  Love, Charlie & Lynn

(mounds of miss-el-toes)

on side
Is ames? in Mexico? We sure regret that we missed J.C. at U. of MO. I see Sam got you: the gold balance is

back in deed?

'68
The Day of the Dead, Mexico
Cheeks puffed full as fat old Wind's,
Brown woman round from head to bare toe
Blows life into the censer breathing
Blue musk over her man below,
While the children shout and tumble about
In the tree with the octupus arms.
Beside a grave gay with white flowers
The women are sharing their bread,
They shake with laughter as they draw nearer
To that democratic Day of the Dead.
Now each family is complete:
Dead lovers to the loved appear,
Brothers, grandmas, mothers' spirits come
For the reunion of the year,
And the children shout and tumble about
In the tree with the octupus arms.
Brown tears from blood-brown candles drip,
The flames boast, "We are immortal",
And blaze around the homemade box
Of one only ten days mortal.
A favored family kneels and weeps--
Wealthy and poor here are the same--
And their rich tears fall on loose fresh dirt,
Still thick on the tongue his name,
But the children shout and tumble about
In the tree with the octupus arms.
Petals pale as a midday moon,
A cross in wilting petals dressed
Alone on a mound of trampled earth
Which humble hands have blessed.
Penny candles, glad little suns,
Light a darkening village under a spreading tree
Where, in meeting, the living and the dead
Come alive on this day,
As the children shout and tumble about
In the tree with the octupus arms.
Lynn Perry-Miller
lovely, Lynn
Host and Guest
Born from a thawing chunk on the warm hearth,
it reconnoitered my room to the south still
to roost above a river of register heat
and fold its wings, a metamorphosed worm.
Here was a visitor a poet could afford,
a speckled bit of flight as calm as a flower
that seemed to live on broken bits of sunbeam---
ultra-violet lunch and infra-sunset supper!
My snow-salted pines were gauged by tiny eyes
whose sun-taught body poised for sunny slopes,
denying those drifts (fallen clouds, hard mist?)
but I who happened to be the temporal host,
I waited on pensive wings a week, two weeks, 
bringing lettuce, apple and pumpkin rind,
jailing my lonely angelic insect from its faith.
O airy flesh and wing-borne dreams,
how evilly I kept you here,
secure from your snowscape of belief!
Charles Miller
Charlie
Best, from an old butterfly! unclear
How's Gladys?

WORLD EYE BOOKSHOP
14 Dec 69
Dear Jack,

We opened this little bookshop (3,000 titles) in downtown Greenfield, and it promises to be a real service to

book readers. We are very busy, & Lynn is very happy. She will be in charge, I will be advising & assisting.
We made the shelves, the counter, the sign etc. & G'field has taken us up very nicely, for it is their first
real modern bookshop.

Jack, I found a recent pile of Disinherited in a warehouse. should I buy then all for you? - or (only, alas)

30% off list price? Let me know.

Thanks for your card, & the dangling career?. We will get a card out, one of these months.
 Love,   Charlie & Lynn

19 1/2 Federal Street, Greenfield, Mass. 01301

Miller.Shinner Rd
Shelburne, Ma 01370
stamp 1c, 1c
postmark U.S. POSTAL SERVICE, MA APR 8 1974  PM
Jack Conroy, Esq.
701 Fisk
Moberly, MO 65270

6 apr.
Dear Jack Sans Ben[u?]e:

 Long time no word from moberly mecca, what makes? Who? Now that the Depression nationed?

you must be man of ease. did you see my mug in that Pub Row rogues gallery of PW April 1, '74? It's a
chapter from my book which is about World eye, books, buns, & why the matt[rers?] is good terrain.

Our seeds are in, some up. Me too.    Love, Charlie, Lynn

Dear Jack,

 Much joy here, in bud, bloom, garden work, goats a-herding, kins a-settin, garden growing. our hot bed giveth?

lettuce & ?eing. World Eye does its thing. Lynn & I dug up septic tank line & replanted it - swiftly flows the shit.
We have a 'new' 67 pick up truck, and a new farm up the line is about to go with it. Lynn is in stitches about building a new ^stone cottage in the woods!
I've got stone hammers in both hands, ball & chain on feet, and I haven't gotten my best balls, yet.

We are deep in nuclear politics here: shall Franklin County have a 1.5 billion - $$ nuclear plant along the Colonial Connecticut River? most of 12%

unemployed say yes, but we others are flexing our muscles for the big NO. Middleton Conn. killed it out, can we do the same?

Thanks muchly for the Traven bit, enclosed. Who knows? most of us are content to know the books.
Working is Gig w/s?. we eve read it! Also Conroy, poems. We sell Conroy, not only because we love'im, but because he's good readin!
Do keep the faith, & keep up on your pamphlets.   Lynn & Laur[?] send oodles of love, as does this old sock, between mowings.     C

card
GUINNESS FOR STRENGTH
image of cart, horse, man

postcard
stamp 8c
postmark GREENFIELD MA APR 1 1975 PM
Dear Jack & Gladys:

we wonder how you are, and if you get enough Guinness? Has April come

to MO? - we still have March & inches of snow. We are too busy, & even when
I'm not, I find it difficult to write good works in a worsening world. We still sell
Traven, Conroy & Agnes Smedley!  write?!     Love, Charlie
on side Lynn & Laur say hiii!
Jack Conroy, Esq.
701 Fisk
Moberly, Mo. 65270

Text is upside down
DATE
Dear Jack,
long time no word, but here's a peach for your larder - add a bit of brandy, to taste!
If you are under the weather, please know that I am, too: a modest heart attack in mid-Dec, & a pleasant stay in hospital a few safe doors from Terminal ward! - & I'm home with Lynn & our Josh (13 1/2, skier, artist & all boy). I'll be almost new in a month or so.
My unclear is still getting reviewed. Did unclear send you a copy?
Love, 
Charlie
The Last Peach
My ladder leaned at sunset's ruddy roof
when it was touch and go if I could pluck
(in a moment before the first black frost)
just short of my grasp as I gambled limbs,
the tree's and mine, to claim that classic fruit
a season had ripened for me, I figured,
reaching up and up for that nubile flesh,
to meet the pinhead gaze of a golden bee
tentacled tight to peach's solar check,
forager's last flight from a storeyed hive,
astronaut on asteroid, frozen to attention---
icy air arriving wave on wave, congealer
of planets, guardian of vagrant galaxies
while I puffed steam pinioned under stars
as I pondered a peach's cooling globe.
Charles Miller
(a recent poem, in tune w/ the Times!)

Miller, Charles H.
Greetings 
to Jack

Heath, Mass. 01346    2 sep 85 Labor Day
Dear Jack,

your WEED KING collection is a triumph. Please accept my congrats, and know what pleasure, what

vindication, you've brought to this worker emeritus.

The title story is excellent, a classic, but my very favorite is 'The Fields of Golden Glow', a family classic;

your mother lives in its pages, and so does the Place, the Moberly, the Monkey Nest landscape of other years.
Of course I liked 'Charlie..,' related to the Shummy and Mink of my farm days; and 'Bun Grady' is a classic
which Gorki must have loved when he read it in the American section of Moscow Library! Well, Jack, I liked
your real collection very much, and will see to it that local bookstores and libraries latch onto it. Wixson sure
did his part, too.

We are well, at work and as embattled asany [sic] family on the make. Since we sold the Book shop 5 years ago

we have been a bit beseiged for taxes, mortgage payments and cash to keep us fed & clothed. Lynn is now a
psychology counsellor [sic], but takes only elder and poverty cases; she is planning to get her Doctor's, by
bits. Loren Lark is 5'10" at age 15, a school athlete and a popular guy; of course he's ready to beat his old man
at almost anything, but so far I've survived.

My AUDEN memoir is yet fighting for pb and UK publication, and hasn't earned its advance, despite fihe [sic: the]

critical reception. The harvest fields and slums of my Midwest are mentioned in it, but not featured. I've finished a
new neo-Travenian novel of Latin America.

We do think of you and wish you the best, Jack.

h/w As ever,  Charlie Miller
P.S. oh yes. NYT Bk. Rev. properly praised your Disinherited. yea!

in pencil Miller, Charlie
Heath, Mass 01346
4 March 86
Dear Jack,

we are getting ass-deep in Berkshire snow these days & wondering how you are doing in Tropical Moberly?
Did your cataract operation help your eyes? and are you able to read as much as you please?
 I take it that you didn't much like my feeble (unpublished) review of your Weed King stories? It isn't ^ easy

to get any good writing published these days, but you've done all right. I have an essay on B. Traven coming
out in Penn. State. Un. Press Collection, & will send you it, this year. Otherwise, I'm collecting rejection slips
& looking for my reward in heaven (a hell of a long delay!).

 Malcolm Cowley had a bout of pneumonia & went to hospittle [sic] but got out alive. He's a great walker & he

hates being 'off his feet'. he's now 87, but has possibilities of the nineties. he's a wonderful guy to be around, & has
been a constant friend.

If you don't have time or inspiration to write this back-slider in the ox-dunged Berkshires, I'll just rely on the good

memories.            always, & as ever

           Charlie       (3 cheers for Red Warren!)

on side  I have 3 books looking for publishers so am always engaged

in pencil Miller, Charlie
typed letter
Miller/ Heath, Mass 01346
6 May 87
Dear Jack,

here's hoping that this finds you strolling among the Maytime flowers of Missouri, like we're hobbling among

the snow-laden crocii in brrrrr-y Berkshires.

How goes the memoir project?
I thought of you while reading B. Traven: Life and Work (Penn State Univ. Press, '87) which has many fine essays on

Traven, including my own, which is partly anarchism in The Treasure of the Sierra Madre and a bit on Charlie Miller
working w/Traven in the 60s, and how Traven's family welcomed our fair Lynn to Mexico.

You ought to have a review copy, so I enclose an addressed envelope. It's a big book, and a good one. We await reviews.
I hope you're enjoying the Iran-Contra Circus in the Senate Caucus Room via TV, a worthy soap opera, which ought to

end by sending RR back to his California dude ranch.

 Lynn and I just celebrated the 20th Anniversary of our meeting at The Newberry in Chicago in May '67, at which time we

began living together, and still do. Our Lark is now a bit taller than I am, and has his Operator's Licence [sic], for hunting
rock concerts and rosy girls. We sit at home and pray for his live return.

Jack, I just finished a novel, EARTH FAMILY, which you'll like, if you liked Dreiser's DAWN. it's a kind of family memoir,

fictionalized when necessary. I wait for a contract.

 Meantime, I'm writing ^ an essay 'Memories of B. Traven in Mexico.' Those were the days. But these aren't bad.

Do drop us a line

h/w Ever yrs, Charlie   on side Lynn is more beautiful & lovin each year. you remember our visit to you in Moberly?

PS

oh yes, Jack: last night my beanpole Loren Lark

challenged me to an arm-wrestle, and I won! - to his
& Lynn's delight.

I still cut wood/saw & axe (no chain saw)

& enjoy my septugenarian health.    Shol!
postcard picture of building and stone sculpture

Dear Jack,
ole sock, were thinking of you while we shovel our first highland snowflakes.
We are glad to hear that The Newberry Library is interested in having your papers in their marble halls! Congrats.
Best wishes as ever,
Charlie & Lynn
Doorstep (Miller Charles H.)
Along our half-mile meadow this monument 
awaits, unearned by us, a heaped-up legacy 
from our departed colonials, a rough
longhouse of lichened rocks and stones
that tripped George Washington's men, grey-faced
green-tint, purple, quartzite and red. All kinds
and shapes unearthed by first or plow, lugged
here by muscle plowmen or stone-boated by ox
to the growing heap. 'And still they pop
up like perennials,' said old Doug, the last
dirt farmer here.
Now we mount our monument
to creen across our clover meadow, once
a woodland slope, then stony-batter pasture.
We spy a buried layered table rock
that took tempestuous eons to form itself
for our doorstep. We pry it out and prop
it up with lesser stones. We step across 
dumb rock. But we hear striated voices rise
from unrecorded centuries. We tap our feet
on a prehistoric slab, and we turn to face
a time that teeters on roiled rocks of the past. 
Charles Miller
Health
December 1988

We are up to our image of eyes in snow.
hope you're enjoying balmy MO.!
drawing of house, trees, snow

h/w apdo 633/ Cuernavaca, Mor [Mexico]
17 april
typed letter
Dear old Jack,

 this won't do at all, this moberlized silence. Speak up, every month or so, or I'll be inclined to send Mexican

roses.    Lynn and I are very busy, writing a book about surviving Zapatistas, doing a collection of Traven's
letters, finishing a documentary film on Zapatalandia and otherwise just trying to write poems, stories, and
love letters.

we now have two very fine mountain horses, that is, all purpose Morelos horses capable of mt. trails, long

valley gallops and general village use. They are very beautiful, and were just a Xmas present; if bought north
of Moberly, they'd be out of our wallet-ability; here, they're like 60. (us.) apiece.

Lynn puts out more poems than I do. I'll see if she has a copy of one for you. And we are reading as usual.

Womack's book on Zapata was much needed, and it serves scholars, but there is much to be said for the spirit
of Zapatistas that scholars can't seem to say (not even in footnotes!)  so we're trying. We also read Yeats, Hardy,
Wells etc. I'm finishing Mailer's ARMIES OF THE NIGHT, a truly impressive book. Ah, our America, now
that Mailer is here.

We hoist a Dos Equis (XX) now & then for you, but we are running out of tracts and hardly know how to voyage

thru the scummy shoals of Today without your guidance m your dictums. I need one on Sexual Restraint, Lynn
needs one on Not Kissing Horses and we can always ^ use one on The Ten Commandments and how to negotiate
them. Thou Shalt Not Forgett [sic] us, pio john.

h/w  Love  Charlie and Lynn

on side  We hear from Herbert &Virginia who are both doing fine. Herbert is opening a gallery downtown clie?

so I'm not running out of tracts, but I've learned to do in Chicago as Chicagoans don't dare do!

Got a note from Rucs ones? enroute to Spain. As for me, I'm enroute to Mexico, sometime
in July and expect to come back here in Sept. - I'm a regular Mexican.

How's everything in Moberly?  Best to you & yours,     Charlie

Dear Jack:

Sorry I invaded your morning office hours, my only face time in Chicago.
 your estimate of the 'papers' is exciting - and helpful!
I want to assure you that, (if you decide to 'commit' the letters to an

institution) no one needs to know about it but you and the institution
or library. The telling letters can be kept in wraps for as long as you wish.
They are considered to be for posterity, and certainly not for contemporary
gossips.    will you give me a few weeks to get a bid on your papers?

I'm trying for two separate bids: 1) your books, mss, and anvils;

2) the letters.

this will bring more coin to you for your maison du Moberly.
Please let me know if I can plan on a few weeks of 'exclusive'

agenting for you?        Best,  Charlie
P..S. on the ^ AT&SF 'Chief' I'm enjoying your anyplace, and can
easily spot your spiffy, slangy prose.   Good job!

in pencil Miller, Charlie [no date]
% The Newberry
60 W. Walton
Chicago 10
31 March
Dear Jack:

so I'm reading my eyes out at the N-bery, but not writing my pen out, not yet. It's a palace of pleasure, I mean

reading pleasure, man, and I like it.

Haven't met La Nicholan as yet:  she comes in at 10:49, goes out for lunch at 10:51, and ^ doesn't come back

the next day! I'd say, she has a good job, wish I had.

I plan to go to hear Jack Conroy in his cups?, at Midland author's' Binge on april 29.
Will you please get your precious letters & mss up out of the bilge hold and into your library? Each time the 

rain starts here I start
on side I read Sworbig's Doleset?, a good job

sweating, for the future of those letters & mss. there.

It was wonderful being in yr home and getting such splendid help on the tequila! Hope to see Moberly again.
 Best, to yr hearth (& dry mss)     Charlie

_____________________________________
P.S. april 2.  I phoned Margaret Jean & had a good gab - you've got a loyal (un-leat? daughter there!

also talked to Arna, nice guy, on phone.   Still wrangling & wrangling my schedule in Indiana, Illinois & Mich. But

I will contact you around april 15. I hope you'll skin-dive the Nelson A. letters from lower decks, & dehydrate other
things as well.   Love  C
on side  PS Didn't phone you & Margaret Jean as yet, but I will.

1-12-74
Dear Jack -

Third class bulk mail is what they throw under the wheels when the mail truck gets stuck,

so it may take more time yet to get your other ANVILs. I thought this regular 3rd class
might be a little faster.    We've filled orders for 2 paperbacks of WIR so far, which ain't
bad for around here, where people don't read much that isn't on the Dayton's best seller list.

Congrats on good sales in Chicago.  Have sent a bundle to Forlkilles - now we need to bill em.
 Salud,   Jack Miller

on side P.S. Will send bundle of SIX more to you by separate mail.  J

May 20, 1968
letterhead
Mrs. Joseph H. Miller
6825 South Hermitage Avenue
Chicago, Illinois 60636
Dear friends -

We were pleasantly surprised to find your card when we came hoe from the Loop. The bluffs and rock

formations looked quite beautiful, but we also have been anxious to see you folks and Moberly, too. As Joe
is retiring August 21, this year and we too are planning to go West in September, we wondered if a few days
trip arriving in Moberly Tuesday, June 25th and staying a couple of days would be convenient for you folks.
Joe has a month's vacation starting June 23rd to Jus damaged but we want to be in Chicago as it damaged
July for another little Harder is to be welcomed near July 11th.

We called Greyhound and the schedule is leave Chicago at 11:45p.m. - arrive in Columbia, Missouri at 8:35 a.m. -

get in Moberly at 12:15 mid-day. if you have plans for this date, we could postpone visit until Spring 1969.

I called Mary Ann and asked her if she wanted to feel old - it is hard for us to believe the Swartz boys

II
are old enough to be University students. But then Carol's Mike will be going into senior year at high school
in September. At that time Harders will have 4 teen-agers in high school.

Joe, too applied for his social security, and it is true that few people will be buying mink and diamonds with

their checks. Joe will get a "modest pension: from Bd. of Ed. Joe worked under S.S. the first 12 lean years of
the system.

Whatever you heard or read in the papers about the riots in Chicago is all true. It is almost unbelievable the

damage done and 20 million dollars arson damage to a beautiful store like Carson, Pirie, Scott & Co. Many
workmen are working constantly, but they will be months repairing & replacing I fear to see what west Madison St.
looks like. And, not due to rioting, from 63rd & Halsted north to 59th St is the crummiest, most bedraggled,
pathetic and dead area in the city. You would have to see it to believe it. While we were close, rioting was at least
a few blocks from us.

Not to inconvenience you at home, we could put up at the local hotel. Would sure to nice to see you both again -

'til we hear from you -  Best wishes,   Louise & Joe

postcard
photo of bobolink bird and daisies

postcard
stamp 5c
BOBOLINK...
6/19/68
Dear Gladys & Jack -

Rec'd your recent letter. was in Loop, so purchased our tickets for Moberly.

Will call you when we arrive Moberly June 25th 12:15 midday. don't bother lunch
for us - will get a bite in Columbus as there is a big lay-over. Sounds like you've
been very busy. Today was graduation for David - lots of excitement. Will see
you.   Our best   Louise & Joe
Mr. & Mrs. Jack Conroy
701 Fisk Avenue
Moberly, Missouri 65270

June 30, 1968
Dear Gladys and Jack -

We arrived home in fine time - in fact 20 minutes early. Had just enough time in St. Louis

to have supper in the station. While waiting to board the Chicago bus, a policeman with a
billy stick in hand came up to each group, warning folks to carry no money in hand or much
in person. Told the ladies to carry it in their bosom and didn't catch where he said for the men.
Perhaps in a money belt. He said they had been having trouble in the station.

Forgot to mention that we waited 25 minutes in Columbia beyond departure time for a college

girl. she dashed up in a cab - must have a family

II
with a pull, as I never heard of Greyhound waiting for any one. We s topped at Lambert
air field and many college age kids got off there.

Well, our visit in Moberly will always be a memorable one - had such a nice time, and it was so nice

seeing you folks again. And Jerry was a bonus, as we never thought about him being with you. And we
certainly saw many interesting places through the generosity of your sisters.

Merry Ann brought "Mouse" back - a very happy cat to be home again - though  I wonder why. I hear

they were feeding him half & half. Merry Ann immediately borrowed your book, but she is a fast reader. I started it on bus.

Thanks for everything and we wish you all the best of everything.    Louise & Joe

card
in June & is hoping to go to Southern Illinois U. in the fall. For 2 years, anyway -
Money will be a factor.

Every time something happens around this town, Joe always says, "You know, I like that town

of Moberly." I do, too, but you have your family there - most of them - and we have ours here.

Well, we hope this finds everyone in fine health. Say Hello to Jerry & Margaret Jean & give our

greetings to the sisters & family.      Best Wishes,     Louise & Joe

October 31, 1974
Dear Gladys & Jack -

 You will be shocked to learn that my darling Joe was struck by a truck and died in a nearby hospital

about 2 hours later. It was a terrible shock to learn of it via phone. Merry Ann came as soon as she could, but
she lives 13 miles away, so I went by cab & she & Fran came to the hospital. This happened Oct. 8, but I just 
haven't gotten to writing to all out of town friends. Carol & Bob flew in & stayed 5 days. You may have
remembered that we were in the process of selling our home. We were anxious to get out, but now I hope I
can stay until business affairs are completed.

 Today is Hallowe'en, but there are far fewer children out. We used to count on over 100.
 Best wishes to all,             Fondly,  Louise

Mrs. J. Miller Apt 1B
3110 W. Marquette Road
Chicago, ILL 60629
postmark CHICAGO IL ? DEC 1975
stamp 10 c

Mr. & Mrs. Jack Conroy
701 Fisk Avenue
Moberly, Missouri 65270

in pencil Miller, Louise
December 29, 1975
Dear Gladys & Jack -

 I have thought so much about you two since I got your card and note. Merry Ann & I feel

so bad about Margaret Jean's condition & suffering. We can stand almost anything for
ourselves, but not suffering for our children.

 We have quite a snow today with hazardous road conditions - about 4", but so slippery.

I cancelled a doctor appointment - just blood pressure check-up. I have to take 3 buses each way
& I could visualize all the slipping and sliding around.

 Mike called for me & we spent Christmas Eve with the Doloways - 14 of us. Everyone was

related to someone & some related to quite a few.

 Keep up the good work on the autobiography.
   Love & good wishes,    Louise

in pencil Miller,  Louise
October 12, 1976  Columbus Day.
Dear Gladys & Jack -

 I have thought so often of you and Margaret Jean, but have just failed to write. The 

last you wrote, you said she had cancer.

 Last winter was a "Lost Week End" for me. Lacking ten days I spend with the Doloways

(Merry Ann) I was in the hospital from January 27 to April 8. I had open heart surgery, a
by-pass, and drug poisoning which lost me 32 lbs. in 18 days. I know what it must be to starve
to death. Carol was up here from Oklahoma for 6 weeks, 3 of those taking care of me after I
finally got home to my own apartment.

 However, I have had a very pleasant summer, as many friends & Merry Ann have had me out to

lunch and to church club meetings. Do not go on public transportation - has to be a door-to-door basis.
I did so plan to go to Oklahoma this month, but can't even think of it. But am happy that David, my
22 yr. old mail man grandson from Oklahoma is coming up this Saturday to see me,

and will stay 3 days.

 Naturally, I have scads of time to read. Have recently polished off 2 huge volumes of W. Somerset Maugham's

short stories, his "The Razor's Edge", dozens of paper back,, all the neighbor's magazines and the Tribune, daily
and Sunday issue. O, yes, and Graham's "Wind in the Willow." Have started "Of Human Bondage," but the cruel
poverty, like Dickens, depresses me, so I may skip it.

 It is good thing I am a calm person, easily satisfied, or one could go nuts, being house bound. I take a short walk

most days around my apartment building - it is large, taking most of a short block and around the corner.

 We will be glad when the election is over. To me, neither is a strong candidate, and everyone is tired of the petty

fault-finding. I am registered, but I doubt if I'll make it to the polling place.

 I do hope you all are well - will be glad to hear from you any time.     Love,   Louise Miller

in pencil Miller, Louise [1977]

January 29, 1977

Dear Gladys & Jack -

 I apologize for being to tardy in writing you about losing Margaret Jean. I've thought of you

so often since receiving your card at Christmas time. What can one say to parents who have
lost a child? It is almost more than one can bear. We send our sincere sympathy.

 Hope you have not had even

half the cold weather we have been having. 19 [degrees] below & wind chill factors of 63 [degrees] below.
And the blizzard conditions have caused much suffering. Talked to Carol last nite & she said while many
nights were cold, days had gone back up to 40 [degrees] & 50 [degrees].

 Your boys have all done well - and to think of Jerry in college! Merry Ann's boy, Gus, started high school

in September.

 Gladys, I hope you get some relief or instructions about your eyes. I was to have had surgery on the second

eye last March, but I was in the hospital at that time. Am letting things ride for the present.

 Have been out of the house only once since Jan. 2nd. Friends & neighbors & Merry Ann try to keep me in 

something to read biographies, verse, mysteries - anything - even Reg Bracken's "I hate to Cook Book",
Sure hated to hear of Agatha Christie's death. did you read her last book, "Sleeping Murder" & "Curtain"
which brings about Hercule Poirot's demise?

 Hope this finds you both well.      Love,  Louise    in red: Miller

in pencil Miller, Frances [no date]

Dear Jack & Gladys,
 So what did you publish or ?goint this past year - lots, I hope!
 Bonnie works for the American Library Ass'n, and has been told

to watch out for publications, but has not said anything lately.

 She was married in Sept to a delightful young man she met at Columbia

and just recently had her first sketch published in a Chgo literary magazine
underline Nit & Wit, /underline I was surprised at how good it is!

 Cheers!

printed Greetings and may the season bring you every happiness

 Mary Frances Miller,  Tom & Bonnie Chronzarls

card image of church, houses, snow, sleigh
A Joyous Christmas!

Jack, what has happened to you? The only thing I've heard is that you told the 

College of   Conplexes that you're an old man, and couldn't come to their
Anniversary party ??? Hope all is well with you?

 Occasionly [sic] hear from Jim Crenslaw - Gentleman Jim had open heart

surgery some time ago and still has some problems, but the mind is still
great -     Mary Frances

Feb, 16. '39
1124 S. Normandie Ave.
Los Angeles, Calif.
in pencil, circled: answered JC Feb 27

Dear Jack Conroy:
 You have probably forgotten me, but I was glad to receive your announcement

about the New Anvil. Here's a check for $1.50. Will try to get subs for you.

 I recovered my health and am married now, to an American born Japanese girl.

she writes, also. Am following the same underline line /underline of thought
and work. We are publishing semi-monthly called "Doho" (meaning "Fellow Countrymen")
which is the only anti-war Japanese paper in the country, having very hard time, though.
I will put you on our mailing list. Will welcome anything you will write for us. The paper
is, as you will see, a people's front publication

printed half in English and half in Japanese. We can not come too left as that might
cut ourselves away from our fellow countrymen who are becoming quite nationalistic,
thanks to Japanese Government publicity forces.

 Will write a better letter soon.

Friendly   Edo Mita
P.S.  Organized Japanese writers (just any and every writers) in L.A., S.F. and Seattle
about two years ago.

 Published my collection of poems in Japanese about same time.
 Geo. Furiya who translated Kensaku Shimaki's "Prison" for the Masses is staying with me.

He is writing his own story in English, now. Still a kid, needs advices. Will write about him in my
next letter.       E.M.

DENIS MITCHELL FILMS LIMITED/ 11 Flask Walk, Hampstead, London N.W. 3. Hampstead 5520
timothy - Lindd  30 July '64     6:30 pm Sunday 9th

 Very pleasant to hear from you. Do please give me a ring will arrange something. The sooner the

better - I have a film in the offing. I'll be away on August 6th-8th, & then from the 15th for a month or so.

 Yours sincerely     D? Fitner

PRINCETON UNIVERSITY
Department of English
August 18, 1947
Dear Jack:

I don't know why it is, but I always seem to get demoralized during the summer, especially if I take on a

little teaching, as I have this summer. I've been meaning to answer your good note every [sic] since it came.
We made Chicago for one day coming east by the U of C was paying the freight & I had to let them write the
program. But surely we must get together at the first opportunity. I shall keep the address & telephone number
on top & call you the first chance I get.     Arthur Mizener.

in pencil [Helen Moberly] [1972] 2014 Stevens Ave. Elkhart 46514

Sun. Nite -

Dear Jim -

Am leaving here next Sat. afternoon by bus - it takes 2 days - will put the departure time and arrival

time on the end of this, after I call in the morning.

 As to a room for me, I cant afford $7 00 a night. I hope I can find a job soon after I get there, as I

don't have a lot of money -

 Mon. morning
  I leave here at 1:50 Sat. - arrive Miami 6:55 - Monday morning - I'll be worn out, but to take a train

I would have to go to Niles, Mich - not one passenger train

2
stops in Elkhart any more.

A plane I can't afford, and any way Im [sic] a "chicken" about flying -

never having flown.

 See you Monday Morning.
   God Bless    Helen

Dear Jack:

 Many thanks for the autographed copy of The Disinherited. Appreciated your kind words and what is more

the thoughtfulness prompting them. Do hope that our paths will soon cross so we can enjoy or continue our communication -
Regards to Mrs Conroy - Be assured that in daily feeble prayer that Ill [sic] recall you - your precious living and beloved dead.

May the writer and all the persons that God privileged him to work with share
in your prayers. May God ever bless Jacks thoughtful and generous heart..

  Father Moe

17 Irving Mansions

Dear Jack Conroy -
 As long-time admirers of your writing, we hope you will have time

to see us, if only for a drink, before you go on to Kent.

 Mrs. Haysblum having been away explains why we haven't been able to

reach you by phone - we still haven't overcome

our American use of the telephone enough to realize that writing a note can 
reach people, too!

 Do call us - we'll keep the weekend of the 22nd free to suit your schedule. 

Our number is FULham - 0336. We are close to Shepherds Bush/ We hope you
have time to see us.

 We're eager to hear news of Charlotte, Chicago and you.
Sincerely,  Jane (& Pete) Molson    Cynthia  in pencil [1960's]

in pencil  Buck [1960's]
TRIDENT PRESS
630 Fifth Avenue
New York 20, N.Y.

Jack:
 Some how your note to me got to the bottom of a pile and stayed there.

I am, until now, very understaffed and half out of my mind. A copy of
underline Long Old Road /underline goes to you post haste under
separate cover. I goofed - sorry. How the hell are you, you old bastard?

 Best Always,    Buck
